abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value:
Samuel Zagat was a Lithuanian-Jewish artist best known for his work as a cartoonist, first for his popular comic strip 
                <emph render="italic">Gimpel Beinish</emph> and later for his political cartoons. This collection documents Zagat's career as a cartoonist and more generally illustrates the efforts of an American cartoonist working in Yiddish. Materials include photographs, original drawings, negatives, contact prints, and newspaper clippings. Major subjects include labor relations, anti-Semitism, Cold War diplomacy, Israel and the Middle East, and humorous aspects of daily Jewish life.

p.value: Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
The collection was donated by Ida Zagat-Rogers, Samuel Zagat's widow, in the early 1970s.

Samuel Zagat (1890-1964), a Lithuanian-Jewish artist and cartoonist who emigrated to New York City as a child. Zagat is best known for his comic strip 
                <emph render="italic">Gimpl Beinish</emph>, published in the Yiddish-language newspaper 
                <emph render="italic">Warheit</emph> from 1912 to 1919, and later for his political cartoons published in the 
                <emph render="italic">Jewish Daily Forward</emph> from 1919 until his death in 1964. 
                <emph render="italic">The Forward</emph>, where Zagat also headed the art department and supervised the newspaper's weekly rotogravure feature, also published his drawings of street life, court sessions, and theater. His cartoons and drawings also appeared in numerous other publications, including the 
                <emph render="italic">New Masses</emph>, 
                <emph render="italic">Jewish Morning Journal</emph>, and 
                <emph render="italic">The Hat Worker</emph>, a publication of the Hat, Cap, and Millinery Workers Union.

This collection documents Samuel Zagat’s career as a cartoonist and more generally illustrates the efforts of an American cartoonist working in Yiddish. The collection contains photographs, original drawings, negatives (presumably taken from the screen of a microfilm reader), contact prints of negatives, newspaper clippings, and photocopies of Zagat’s cartoons from the 1910s through the 1960s. The majority of the materials are from the 1940s and 1950s. Major subjects include labor relations, anti-Semitism, Cold War diplomacy, Israel and the Middle East, and humorous aspects of daily Jewish life. A substantial portion of Zagat’s cartoons contain Yiddish captions; the majority of materials in this collection have supplied English translations.

dsc.value:
Original Drawing Portfolios Arrangement

This series is arranged into ten portfolios based on the cartoons’ thematic subjects.

 Scope and Content Note

This series consists of ten portfolios of original drawings by Samuel Zagat. The drawings were grouped into portfolios concerning specific subjects, including economics, World War II, anti-Semitism, Cold War diplomacy, daily Jewish life, Israel and the Middle East, and American domestic and foreign policy. Reference photocopies of the drawings from portfolios 1-7 and 9-10 are available, and may aid researchers in browsing the collection.

 Portfolio 1: Capital and Labor 1 1-9 1933-1946, undated Portfolio 2: United States Political Cartoons 1 10-17 undated Portfolio 3: International Politics 2 1-7 1955-1959, undated Portfolio 4: Israel, Near East, Anti-Semitism 2 8-11 1955-1959, undated Portfolio 5: Jewish Humor 3 1-14 4 1-15 1955, undated Portfolio 6: USSR Box MSXOS001 1 5 1-9 1955-1971, undated Portfolio 7: Nazis 6 1 Box MSXOS001 1 undated Portfolio 8: The Hat Worker 7 1-24 1920-1961 Portfolio 9: USA Miscellaneous 6 2-3 Box MSXOS001 1 undated Portfolio 10: Works Exhibited March 7, 1974 Box MSXOS001 1 6 4-6 undated Reference Photocopies: Portfolios 1-4 and Index 14 1933-1959 Reference Photocopies: Portfolios 5-7, 9-10 15 1920-1971 Cartoons by Publication Arrangement

This series is arranged alphabetically by title, thereunder chronologically.

 Scope and Content Note

This series consists of prints and negatives of Samuel Zagat’s comic strips and political cartoons. Included are individual cartoons and several of Zagat’s long-running comic strips, like Gimpl Beinish. Topics include labor relations, anti-Semitism, Cold War diplomacy, and humorous aspects of daily Jewish life.

Arrangement

This series is arranged chronologically.

 Scope and Content Note

This series consists of prints of Samuel Zagat’s political cartoons that appeared in a variety of unidentifiable publications. Topics include economics, labor relations, anti-Semitism, Cold War diplomacy, and humorous aspects of daily Jewish life.

 9 5 1912 9 6 1913 9 7 1914-1915 9 8 1916 9 9 Jan 1917-Mar 1917 9 10 Apr 1917 9 11 May 1917-Dec 1917 9 12 1918 6 15 circa 1935 Negatives 13 112-180 Apr 27, 1917-Dec 1959 Lower East Side Photographs Arrangement

This series is arranged chronologically.

 Scope and Content Note

This series consists of negatives and 56 8 x 10 black-and-white photographs by Zagat on New York City’s Lower East Side in 1931 prior to the Jewish high holidays of Rosh Hashanah and Sukkot. The photographs include images of people on a pier (probably near the East River), many of them holding what are probably prayer books and presumably waiting to perform the Tashlikh, a Rosh Hashanah custom in which celebrants gather by a body of flowing water and turn their pockets out, symbolically casting off their sins. Other photographs depict shoppers purchasing the ritual Sukkot items lulav and esrog (a palm front bound together with willow branches and a citrus fruit, respectively) from street vendors, as well as merchants selling skullcaps, shoes, and dishes at outdoor stands. Most locations are not identified. Some items in this series were published in the Jewish Daily Forward.

 Photographs shot by Samuel Zagat on New York City's Lower East Side (18 prints) 9 13 1931 Photographs shot by Samuel Zagat on New York City's Lower East Side (12 prints) 9 14 1931 Photographs shot by Samuel Zagat on New York City's Lower East Side (12 prints) 9 15 1931 Photographs shot by Samuel Zagat on New York City's Lower East Side (14 prints) 9 16 1931 Negatives from Jewish Life on New York’s Lower East Side 10 267-381 circa 1931
